title: Review: Bringing better governance to real-world communities with quadratic funding
body:
**TL;DR: city3 and Gitcoinâ€™s first local quadratic funding experiment saw 7 Oakland nonprofits raise \~$4,000 from 240+ unique contributors. In this recap we share the opportunities and challenges in bringing innovative governance models to offline communities.**

City3â€™s mission is to create more just socio-economic systems powered by crypto for existing real world communities. As part of this effort, we recently partnered with [Gitcoin](https://gitcoin.co/) to bring quadratic funding to the city of Oakland.

[Quadratic funding](https://wtfisqf.com/?grant=&grant=&grant=&grant=&match=1000) (QF) is a mathematically and democratically optimal way to fund public goods, where matching capital is distributed based on a quadratic formula that makes the number of contributors matter more than the amount raised.

![Quadratic funding explained (EOS)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8CJudW5yeHroHo9FiCaH2.png?height=415&width=768)

We originally set out with three broad questions outlined in our [announcement](https://mirror.xyz/0xcity3.eth/8ZgDDZcixWbLW9Jb79Vuc5illbB5IiKU-c-NyCfabEQ):

* Is supporting an organization that you care about an effective incentive for someone to set up a web3 wallet?
* What can quadratic funding tell us about the way people value civic organizations?
* Will small dollar contributors feel theyâ€™ve made a significant contribution?

In this article we highlight two major takeaways from the experience:

1. **To optimize positive results, we should identify the types of decisions and/or public goods that thrive when QF is applied.** We recommend a stronger alignment with the two problems QF is designed to address: information asymmetry and the free rider problem.
2. **Governance experiments need to prioritize building trust, accessibility and diverse representation.** Funding real-world public goods comes with its own set of challenges, but existing tools are not designed for offline communities. This is an open call for more QF projects â€œin the wildâ€.

# Overview and results

During [Gitcoin Grants Round 14](https://gitcoin.co/blog/gr14-results/) which ran from 8-23 June 2022, 7 Oakland nonprofits raised $3,799.07 from 454 contributions and 249 unique contributors. $15,000 has been set aside for matching, funded jointly by city3 and the [Oakland Fund for Public Innovation](https://www.oaklandfund.org/).

![Gitcoinâ€™s quadratic funding local cause round for Oakland](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eh6o2W2RW1rMLSWhG70zd.png?height=1488&width=1830)

Although contributing to the round was open to anyone, we hosted a series of virtual governance workshops aimed at assisting locals with setting up a non-custodial crypto wallet and Github account, and then navigating Gitcoinâ€™s checkout process.

During these workshops we saw firsthand how most web3 tools are simply not designed for offline communities, let alone mobile-first users.

Yet despite the friction, several residents expressed surprise that crypto could be used in this way. For those interacting with crypto for the first time, there was something viscerally meaningful about seeing a $5 donation get matched with $30 for an organization in their community. Those already familiar with crypto expressed a desire to see more of these initiatives:

> *â€œI am currently working full time for a DAO, and it's cool how global it is, but would love to get more involved \[with\] local web3/crypto efforts.â€*

Exact numbers on local participation are not available, but by combining Gitcoinâ€™s profile location data with the number of people who attended our governance workshops and/or responded to our feedback surveys, we estimate that 20% of contributors were Oakland residents.

Clearly, there exists some critical threshold at which representation either justifies or undermines the entire quadratic funding process. This also highlights why education and accessibility are so important, and ought to be considered integral to any effective quadratic funding program.

Consider a hypothetical grants round with higher-stakes decisions. While outside funding might still be useful to maximize funds raised, would we still weigh votes equally between locals and non-locals? Weâ€™re excited about the early although untested solutions that attempt to solve this, such as intersectional social data (see [RadicalxChange](https://www.radicalxchange.org/media/blog/2019-10-24-uh78r5/)) or geo-spatial weighting (see [Astral Protocol](https://docs.astral.global/) or [Foam](https://foam.space/)).

# Where does quadratic funding matter most?

In their 2020 paper, *[Building Radical Cities](https://assets.website-files.com/5d253237e31f051057dc0a2b/5f04beb70336ec0cc37ceff9_Building%20Radical%20Charter%20Cities.pdf)*, Paul Healy and Matt Prewitt identify QF as one of several mechanisms to better calibrate political expression at the city level. QF has been a popular choice for distributing public grants in the cryptosphere. For example, Gitcoin Grants Round 14 saw record breaking numbers: over 44,000 contributors donated $1.7M which will be boosted by a $3.2M matching pool.

Just as QF supports â€œlong tailâ€ crypto projects â€“ novel, smallÂ initiatives that otherwise would not be able to accumulate startup capital â€“Â we set out to test whether the same could be applied to long tail â€œreal-worldâ€ projects, particularly civic organizations that play a critical role in serving their communities. While several offline projects have raised funds with Gitcoin in the past, this was the first time matching was targeted at a specific geographic community.

We are incredibly proud to have worked with Oakland nonprofits doing important work ranging from tech mentorship to supporting gang-impacted youth. And while we believe that nothing bad happens when impactful community organizations get money they deserve, in hindsight we do question whether funding local nonprofits was the most useful application of this governance tool.

The benefit of QF lies not so much in matching large sums of capital to small donations as in surfacing the nuance of community preferences in order to produce the best possible allocation outcome for decisions involving competing public goods.

Here we turn to the two problems QF is most cited to solve:

1. **QF solves an information problem.** In a world of scarce resources, the government (or more broadly, the public) does not always know how much of a certain good to provide
2. **QF solves a free rider problem.** Those who benefit from public goods often underpay or donâ€™t pay at all because there is little incentive to make small, individual contributions.

We believe we could have done a better job of scoping the problem space and designing our QF program to directly address these areas. For our next experiment, we may consider these questions as part of our decision making framework:

1. What are some examples of competing public goods that we find difficult to prioritize in the local city budget?
2. What are some areas of public resource allocation that people frequently complain feels unrepresentative and/or unfair?
3. What are some alternative governance models already being applied in the community (e.g. participatory budgeting, neighborhood council advisory boards) â€“ are they willing to try a new approach?

# A call for more quadratic funding â€œin the wildâ€

Some of our biggest coordination challenges exist at the city level. While there is growing interest in new governance models enabled by web3 technology, we havenâ€™t seen these implemented outside of [a few examples](https://twitter.com/0xcity3/status/1534576283232763905). In other words, whether quadratic funding is indeed democratically and economically optimal is yet to be tested at scale.

We see a massive opportunity to combine the best of tokenized governance with decisions that tangibly affect the communities we live in. Several organizations are already doing work that makes this possible:

* [Gitcoin](https://gitcoin.co/)
* [Endaoment](https://endaoment.org/)
* [Change](https://getchange.io/)
* [RadicalxChange](https://www.radicalxchange.org/)
* [Clr.fund](https://clr.fund/#/)
* [Protocol Labs](https://protocol.ai/)

We hope to see more crypto tools designed to serve real-world communities. For this to happen, we simultaneously need to invest in [pre-existing social infrastructure](https://otherinter.net/research/local-gov/) that has a long legacy of making our cities more just, more livable and more resilient.

# Conclusion

We believe that QF is only as impactful as it is accessible and only as useful as it solves critical problems that could not be solved through simpler means.

The Oakland local cause round was the first of many programs city3 will be launching to bridge web3 innovation with real-world community needs. Just as crypto crowdfunding has expanded possibilities for seeding public goods, we have a unique opportunity to shift resource allocation within our cities.

[Follow us on Twitter](https://twitter.com/0xcity3) to stay up to date with our work.

title: Crypto's Native Frontier
body:
For billions of people around the globe, Web3 represents an opportunity to realize a vibrant new digital world â€“ one that isnâ€™t designed and controlled by a handful of executives in the glass towers of primarily Western megacities.

It isnâ€™t just about economic empowerment, either. 

**Web3 offers transformative potential that stretches deep into the realms of cultural identity, entertainment, and communicationâ€¦ and ultimately into the place where these concepts have converged for thousands of years: gaming.**

The Crypto Revolution is going to reshape our world not because engineers in Silicon Valley are creating a new generation of user technology, but because Web3â€™s diverse participants are creating open infrastructure that people everywhere will use to build new worlds themselves.

Today, gaming is a $200B market composed of 3 billion gamers and the fastest evolving form of media in the world.

In order to understand why gaming will be a core frontier in the context of the social-technological revolution playing out today, we first need to explore gamingâ€™s history and trajectory.

> ## The Very Beginning:

Gaming is as native to human culture as language is (and may even predate it). 

**Serving as an invaluable social mechanism throughout history, weâ€™ve used games to bond, teach, develop our values, and make sense of the world.**

The cradle of civilization that was the Middle East naturally saw the emergence of the first examples. In the 3000s BC, Mesopotamians played The Royal Game of Ur on beautifully painted boards, while the Egyptians played Senet.

Chaturanga would formally appear in India around 600 AD, though examples of its predecessors date back to 3000 BC. The Persians adopted it as Shatranj before European traders brought it over and turned it into Chess.

As far back as 2000 BC, Mesoamericans were playing a ballgame on courts. The activity was of immense societal importance, incorporated in rituals and used to resolve conflicts or even war.

This era also saw Ancient China develop Wei Qi â€“ known today as Go â€“ originally used to practice and refine strategic thinking. Later Chinese dynasties would also invent playing cards and dominoes.

* ***Games have always held enormous societal significance across a variety of contexts â€“ military, social, educational, and entertainment 
 ***
* ***We now think of it as an industry, but throughout the majority of our history gaming was an intrinsic activity that underpinned most of culture 
 ***
* ***We congratulate ourselves for our use of games to teach, train, and connect, when in reality humans have very effectively used games to do all of this for thousands of years 
 ***
* ***Todayâ€™s progressive gamification of society â€“ investing, learning, working, collaborating â€“ is really just a revival of an ancient behavior codified in our brains***

> ## Back to the Future:

German-American engineer Ralph Baer, inspired by the mass production and ownership of televisions as a key primitive, first envisioned a game that could be played on a home television in 1966. The following year, he and his colleagues at Sanders Associates invented a prototype system known as â€œThe Black Boxâ€ â€“ the first multiplayer console video game system, initially licensed under the name of â€œMagnavox Odyssey.â€

* ***This is an important point in the nature of technology: the creation of a new primitive (in this case, televisions) combines with an existing human behavior (gaming) to unlock a universe of new possibilities***

The Odyssey would soon inspire its competitor Atari to launch its own video game in 1972/3, initially an arcade video game called Pong that would later be turned into a version playable at home.

* ***Both the history and future of gaming are underpinned by social connections: yesterdayâ€™s arcades will be tomorrowâ€™s metaverse***

> ## Leveling Up with Composability:

Atari broke new ground in 1977 by launching the Atari 2600 VCS that allowed users to switch out game cartridges via an external ROM slot. Though Atari built dozens of games themselves, their creation of generalizable gaming hardware allowed third-party programmers across the globe to design their own games for the console.

Other novel features included levels with increasing difficulty, scoring systems, and leaderboards, setting the stage for the communities that would soon form around games themselves.

> ## New Entrants:

An intense wave of consumer demand, fueled by the launch of massively popular games like Space Invaders, was followed by a crash in the industry as excessive hype led to an oversupply of cheap games.

The crash wouldnâ€™t last long, however, as a new (yet very old) powerhouse would rise from the East. Nintendo, founded in 1889 as a manufacturer of playing cards, launched a number of titles in the early 1980s that would shape the industry forever, including Donkey Kong, Mario Bros., Zelda, and other major titles.

Nintendo also launched its own console: the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES), featuring significant technological improvements relative to its existing peers.

In 1989, Nintendo made history once more by releasing the first handheld Game Boy â€“ forever transforming the world of gaming and **setting the stage for the mobile revolution that would come many years later**.

As weâ€™ll explore later, gamingâ€™s biggest domain has shifted to mobile, paying homage to one of its earliest and most important innovations.

* ***Consoles were never the endgame â€“ they were the intermediate medium while the hardware and software caught up during a long period of intense development***

> ## Upgrading the Stack:

The console wars of the 1990s saw companies like Sega, Nintendo, and Sony battle for dominance as they leveraged a rapidly evolving technological ecosystem to develop increasingly sophisticated consoles and game franchises.

**In parallel,** **the technological explosion that engulfed the world in the â€˜80s and â€˜90s saw computers enter millions of homes**. 

The tremendous increase in computing power allowed developers to supercharge their efforts, leading to the dawn of three-dimensional gaming experiences and online play.

As more homes came online, LAN parties became extremely popular, with players meeting up in person to compete by connecting to the local network.

The 2000â€™s saw a new era of console wars, this time between Microsoft (Xbox), Sony (Playstation), and Nintendo (Wii), **with** **competition centering on graphics, quality of storyline, and, eventually, the online gaming experience**. Marketplaces sprung up, allowing users to purchase titles or downloadable content, upgrade software, and communicate with other players.

Advanced open world games with simulated autonomous characters also became extremely popular as a predecessor to the digital metaverse boom weâ€™re seeing today.

PC-based MMORPGs became a global phenomenon in their own right, competing less on graphics or story and more on community, digital identity, and portability.

* ***The explosion in PC gaming offered a glimpse of what billions of users would ultimately prioritize in their gaming experiences***

> ## Going Mobile:

Decreasing computing and hardware costs allowed the global gaming audience to grow exponentially over the late 1990s and early 2000s.

**Just as the prevalence of personal computers provided a new medium for the industry to expand into, so too did the billions of mobile phones produced in the late 2000s and early 2010s offer a new route for adoption.**

Mobile gaming continued where PC-based gaming left off, prioritizing experiences that offered portability, simplicity, and community interaction. 

**The rise of mobile phones as the primary computing hardware used by billions of people saw the gaming demographic expand into casual players of all ages**, with low-cost games spinning up to meet every user profile.

The market for mobile games was worth \~$120B in 2021 and is expected to triple over the next decade as the computing stack gets even better.

* ***As with TVs before, the mobile transformation offers further proof of a recurring historical pattern: technological infrastructure introduced for one purpose tends to unlock astonishing value across myriad others 
 ***
* ***Blockchains will likely end up underpinning trillions in value across cultural and social use cases we have yet to imagine, extending well beyond the initial applications in decentralized finance***

> ## Beyond Gaming:

Just as the demographic has expanded tremendously over gamingâ€™s first few decades, so too has its very meaning.

**Two critical developments took place in the late 2010s:**

**1) The ability to integrate real world culture into the game itself**

**2) The creation of in-game economies for digital assets**

Franchises like Fortnite were early pioneers in recognizing that online gaming was as much about the competition as it was about expressing social identity and connecting over cultural movements in an open, digital environment.

* ***The industryâ€™s life cycle has seen a steady convergence of social interactions and traditional gaming, with the former seemingly on track to eventually eclipse the latter in importance***


* ***Ultimately, Fortnite and others have become enablers of a new world in which the peripheral gaming experience often matters most: video streaming, chat, digital cosmetics, microtransactions, etc***

> ## Decentralizing Web2:

The rise of Roblox â€“ a platform facilitating and hosting user-created games â€“ represents another major industry development. **Roblox boasts an incredible \~200M monthly active users, with over 70% of user sessions taking place on mobile devices.**

Just as YouTube broke ground by making video content creation open to everyone, Roblox has turned players into builders (though most users are still only players).

Roblox includes its own in-game currency (Robux) that players can use to purchase items in its digital economy.

The Steam Deck is another fascinating development. 

**Built on an open-source operating system (Linux), the Steam Deck offers cross-platform capabilities** for players to access games from a range of developers, as well as older games using emulation software.

**The rise of Cloud Gaming is another emerging trend making gaming accessible to everyone.** Now, players donâ€™t need to invest in expensive hardware to access incredible games anywhere in the world.

* ***These colossal themes playing out are a major reason why Web3 makes sense as the logical successor domain for gaming: the ideological alignment is extraordinary 
 ***
* ***The shift away from expensive hardware and closed ecosystems, the proliferation of a rich social layer, and the quest for creative ownership are inevitably driving the industry towards a blockchain-enabled future***

> ## Play to Earn:

The blockchain revolution naturally started with financial applications, given the original purpose of Bitcoin itself was to create a peer-to-peer decentralized transaction system. So it shouldnâ€™t be surprising that the tactics that worked early on in DeFi were soon applied to the world of Web3 gaming.

**In particular, two areas saw the most significant amount of early adoption:**

* **Blockchain-enabled marketplaces for in-game digital assets**
* **Native gaming tokens that had in-game utility but more importantly served to reward early players**

However, most of cryptoâ€™s early games have largely been built off-chain, with only the digital economies themselves (exchange and settlement) taking place on-chain.

**Ultimately, these games crashed back to earth due to a few key problems:**

* **Terrible gaming experiences centered on yield generation, inevitably attracting short term mercenaries 
 **
* **Poorly thought-out economies with native governance and utility tokens effectively programmed to go to zero 
 **
* **Closed-wall infrastructure that is neither composable nor interoperable**

> ## Where Weâ€™ve Fallen Short:

The approach to date has essentially been to **take DeFi and build narratives with prehistoric graphics and storylines on top of it**. Predictably, this approach fell into a dangerous purgatory, having failed to attract serious players or even durable traders.

**The next phase of Web3 gaming is gravitating towards improved graphics and storylines, as well as better economic design**. 

This new route wonâ€™t be a walk in the park either.

By competing on the DeFi front, games were effectively fighting for attention using yield. This strategy was nearsighted but admittedly worked in a market that could only go up.

By making graphics and storylines the new industry battleground, Web3 developers are taking on the traditional AAA studios who have an extraordinary head start.

More importantly, truly crypto-native solutions are less likely to get built this way. This approach feels a lot more like the late â€˜90s equivalent of taking every business and throwing â€œ.comâ€ in front of it.

**Builders need to be wary of forcing crypto rails into unnatural use cases.**

The other issue lies in making gaming an asset-based experience at its core, rather than a social one. By doing so, we create barriers to entry that can be exploited by developers, guilds, speculators, and other potentially malicious actors, thereby derailing cryptoâ€™s mission to empower the world.

* ***If crypto-native developers want to win, they need to battle on home ground and on their own terms. Trying to beat the incumbents at their own game is a very challenging (and resource intensive) strategy***

> ## Building On Cryptoâ€™s Unfair Advantage:

The true renaissance will occur as we start leveraging crypto rails to redefine what gaming looks like.

**Part of that centers on the gaming experience:**

* **Interoperability across games** so that players can transport their assets and inventories across different platforms without having to start over. This holds true for identity & in-game achievements as well. This really only works when the game is built entirely on-chain 
 
* **Trustless relationships between players** that conceal strategy and/or protect identity. Zero knowledge technology will be incredibly powerful in enabling these use cases 
 
* **Complete storage of game logic and state on-chain**, removing persistent reliance on developers and creating total transparency around the equality of rules and accomplishments 
 
* Users can shape (and profit from) the direction of games through **governance or direct economic ownership** 
 
* Player inventories and identities become **durable yet dynamic assets** as they experience upgrades or depreciation 
 
* **Games that exist in perpetuity**, free from the constant threat that developers might shut off access

**Another component concerns the construction of games:**

* By building games entirely on-chain, **the creativity of users becomes an asset** in itself as players can use open-source game logic and state to build extensions that capture aspects unique to their culture or real-world experiences 
 
* Rather than AAA game developers trying to interpret and incorporate local themes, **players are empowered to organically design personalized environments** that are infinitely more meaningful by leveraging on-chain primitives 
 
* The Atari 2600 encouraged third-party developers around the world to build new games by making the technological (and capital) hurdle minimal 
 
* Importantly, blockchains also provide a mechanism by which **creators of user generated content can own their work** 
 
* Using open-source, interoperable software to tear down the walls that AAA studios have built up will **set the stage for incredible creativity to flourish around the world.** 

  This version of reality makes winners out of us all 
 

> ## Expanding the Definition:

Another reason for infinite optimism concerns who gamers will be and what gaming will mean.

**The rise of the mobile phone marked a critical turning point in bringing gaming to an exponentially larger audience**: grandparents and children; teachers and athletes; artists and mathematicians.

The â€œwhatâ€ changed as well.

Sophisticated storylines gave way to simple contests like puzzles, spelling bees, chopping fruit, and launching birds. 

**Weâ€™re likely to see that trend continue, with blockchains expanding deep into the domain of classrooms, board meetings, corporate training, sporting events, identity cultivation, and more.**

The interoperable and composable nature of truly crypto-native games will see **a wide range of opportunities for diverse individuals to contribute**: clothing designers who can build skins and outfits for open world environments; graphic designers who can craft remarkable new digital realities; musicians who can incorporate their songs into games, etc.

* ***In an ideal world, the sustainable economies of Web3 games will center on organic user generated value, rather than utility tokens designed to inflate to infinity 
 ***
* ***Blockchain enabled gaming may well prove to be the reserve currency that connects our world through shared, immersive cultural experiences***

> ## Ultimatelyâ€¦

Weâ€™re likely to see hybrid experiments play out in the immediate term. Building compelling games entirely on-chain remains a significant technical challenge, so we can expect **continued innovation around games that primarily live off-chain.**

Further, expect to see sustained creativity around the question of efficiently recording state changes on-chain while preserving true decentralization and efficient performance.

**Supporting infrastructure will be a particularly exciting field in the coming years:**

* **Cross-game NFT marketplaces**
* **Interoperability stacks**
* **Identity primitives derived from in-game activity**
* **Franchise discovery platforms**
* **Low-code tooling** / **SDKs**
* **On/off ramps and specialized wallets**

While a number of very talented developer teams are trying to design rich gaming experiences in Web3 native fashion, it may ultimately be that we see **a continuation of the trend of social and peripheral experiences outweighing the importance of deep storylines and stunning graphics.**

If this proves to the case, however, the on-chain social layer will need to improve drastically. Yields simply arenâ€™t enough to build a sustainable ecosystem of participants.

The decentralized future is incredible exciting, but weâ€™ll only realize its full potential by **building a world for everyone, by everyone**.

* ***History teaches us that the creation of a new technological primitive, when combined with innate human behavior, leads to incredible value creation, with gaming perhaps the most fundamental example of them all 
 ***
* ***Gaming is a universal experience codified into our brains across millennia of social interactions 
 ***
* ***Weâ€™ve previously explored how the crypto revolution represents a reversion to the earliest principles underpinning human commerce. Itâ€™s therefore only natural that one its biggest unlocks sees us return to the roots of our very nature***

Just as the demographic has expanded tremendously over gamingâ€™s first few decades, so too has its very meaning.

**Two critical developments took place in the late 2010s:**

**1) The ability to integrate real world culture into the game itself**

**2) The creation of in-game economies for digital assets**

Franchises like Fortnite were early pioneers in recognizing that online gaming was as much about the competition as it was about expressing social identity and connecting over cultural movements in an open, digital environment.

> ***The industryâ€™s life cycle has seen a steady convergence of social interactions and traditional gaming, with the former seemingly on track to eventually eclipse the latter in importance***

> ***Ultimately, Fortnite and others have become enablers of a new world in which the peripheral gaming experience often matters most: video streaming, chat, digital cosmetics, microtransactions, etc***

## *Decentralizing Web2:*

The rise of Roblox â€” a platform facilitating and hosting user-created games â€” represents another major industry development. Roblox boasts an incredible \~200M monthly active users, with over 70% of user sessions taking place on mobile devices.

**Just as YouTube broke ground by making video content creation open to everyone, Roblox has turned players into builders (though most users are still only players).**

Roblox includes its own in-game currency (Robux) that players can use to purchase items in its digital economy.

The Steam Deck is another fascinating development.

Built on an open-source operating system (Linux), the Steam Deck offers cross-platform capabilities for players to access games from a range of developers, as well as older games using emulation software.

**The rise of Cloud Gaming is another emerging trend making gaming accessible to everyone.**

Now, players donâ€™t need to invest in expensive hardware to access incredible games anywhere in the world.

> ***These colossal themes playing out are a major reason why Web3 makes sense as the logical successor domain for gaming: the ideological alignment is extraordinary***
>
> ***The shift away from expensive hardware and closed ecosystems, the proliferation of a rich social layer, and the quest for creative ownership are inevitably driving the industry towards a blockchain-enabled future***

## *Play to Earn:*

The blockchain revolution naturally started with financial applications, given the original purpose of Bitcoin itself was to create a peer-to-peer decentralized transaction system. So it shouldnâ€™t be surprising that the tactics that worked early on in DeFi were soon applied to the world of Web3 gaming.

> **In particular, two areas saw the most significant amount of early adoption:**

* **Blockchain-enabled marketplaces for in-game digital assets 
 **
* **Native gaming tokens that had in-game utility but more importantly served to reward early players**

However, most of cryptoâ€™s early games have largely been built off-chain, with only the digital economies themselves (exchange and settlement) taking place on-chain.

> **Ultimately, these games crashed back to earth due to a few key problems:**

* **Terrible gaming experiences centered on yield generation, inevitably attracting short term mercenaries 
 **
* **Poorly thought-out economies with native governance and utility tokens effectively programmed to go to zero 
 **
* **Closed-wall infrastructure that is neither composable nor interoperable**

## *Where Weâ€™ve Fallen Short:*

The approach to date has essentially been to **take DeFi and build narratives with prehistoric graphics and storylines on top of it**. Predictably, this approach fell into a dangerous purgatory, having failed to attract serious players or even durable traders.

> **The next phase of Web3 gaming is gravitating towards improved graphics and storylines, as well as better economic design**

This new route wonâ€™t be a walk in the park either.

By competing on the DeFi front, games were effectively fighting for attention using yield. This strategy was nearsighted but admittedly worked in a market that could only go up.

> **By making graphics and storylines the new industry battleground, Web3 developers are taking on the traditional AAA studios who have an extraordinary head start.**

More importantly, truly crypto-native solutions are less likely to get built this way. This approach feels a lot more like the late â€™90s equivalent of taking every business and throwing â€œ.comâ€ in front of it.

**Builders need to be wary of forcing crypto rails into unnatural use cases.**

The other issue lies in making gaming an asset-based experience at its core, rather than a social one. By doing so, we create barriers to entry that can be exploited by developers, guilds, speculators, and other potentially malicious actors, thereby derailing cryptoâ€™s mission to empower the world.

> ***If crypto-native developers want to win, they need to battle on home ground and on their own terms. Trying to beat the incumbents at their own game is a very challenging (and resource intensive) strategy***

## *Building On Cryptoâ€™s Unfair Advantage:*

The true renaissance will occur as we start leveraging crypto rails to redefine what gaming looks like.

> ***Part of that centers on the gaming experience:***

* **Interoperability across games** so that players can transport their assets and inventories across different platforms without having to start over. This holds true for identity & in-game achievements as well 
 
* **Trustless relationships between players** that conceal strategy and/or protect identity. Zero knowledge technology will be incredibly powerful in enabling these use cases 
 
* **Complete storage of game logic and state on-chain**, removing persistent reliance on developers and creating total transparency around the equality of rules and accomplishments 
 
* Users can shape (and profit from) the direction of games through **governance or direct economic ownership 
 **
* Player inventories and identities become **durable yet dynamic assets** as they experience upgrades or depreciation 
 
* **Games that exist in perpetuity**, free from the constant threat that developers might shut off access

> ***Another component concerns the construction of games:***

* By building games entirely on-chain, **the creativity of users becomes an asset** in itself as players can use open-source game logic and state to build extensions that capture aspects unique to their culture or real-world experiences 
 
* Rather than AAA game developers trying to interpret and incorporate local themes, **players are empowered to organically design personalized environments** that are infinitely more meaningful by leveraging on-chain primitives 
 
* The Atari 2600 encouraged third-party developers around the world to build new games by making the technological (and capital) hurdle minimal 
 
* Importantly, blockchains also provide a mechanism by which **creators of user generated content can own their work** 
 
* Using open-source, interoperable software to tear down the walls that AAA studios have built up will **set the stage for incredible creativity to flourish around the world.**

This version of reality makes winners out of us all

## *Expanding the Definition:*

Another reason for infinite optimism concerns who gamers will be and what gaming will mean.

**The rise of the mobile phone marked a critical turning point in bringing gaming to an exponentially larger audience**: grandparents and children; teachers and athletes; artists and mathematicians.

**The â€œwhatâ€ changed as well.**

Sophisticated storylines gave way to simple contests like puzzles, spelling bees, chopping fruit, and launching birds.

**Weâ€™re likely to see that trend continue, with blockchains expanding deep into the domain of classrooms, board meetings, corporate training, sporting events, identity cultivation, and more.**

The interoperable and composable nature of truly crypto-native games will see a **wide range of opportunities for diverse individuals to contribute**

Clothing designers who can build skins and outfits for open world environments; graphic designers who can craft remarkable new digital realities; musicians who can incorporate their songs into games, etc.

> ***In an ideal world, the sustainable economies of Web3 games will center on organic user generated value, rather than utility tokens designed to inflate to infinity***
>
> ***Blockchain enabled gaming may well prove to be the reserve currency that connects our world through shared, immersive cultural experiences***

## *Ultimatelyâ€¦*

Weâ€™re likely to see hybrid experiments play out in the immediate term. Building compelling games entirely on-chain remains a significant technical challenge, so we can expect **continued innovation around games that primarily live off-chain.**

Further, expect to see sustained creativity around the question of **efficiently recording state changes on-chain** while preserving true decentralization and efficient performance.

> **Supporting infrastructure will be a particularly exciting field in the coming years:**

* **Cross-game NFT marketplaces**
* **Interoperability stacks**
* **Identity primitives derived from in-game activity**
* **Franchise discovery platforms**
* **Low-code tooling** / **SDKs**
* **On/off ramps and specialized wallets**

**While a number of very talented developer teams are trying to design rich gaming experiences in Web3 native fashion, it may ultimately be that we see a continuation of the trend of social and peripheral experiences outweighing the importance of deep storylines and stunning graphics.**

If this proves to the case, however, the on-chain social layer will need to improve drastically. Yields simply arenâ€™t enough to build a sustainable ecosystem of participants.

The decentralized future is incredible exciting, but weâ€™ll only realize its full potential by building a world for everyone, by everyone.

> ***History teaches us that the creation of a new technological primitive, when combined with innate human behavior, leads to incredible value creation, with gaming perhaps the most fundamental example of them all***
>
> ***Gaming is a universal experience codified into our brains across millennia of social interactions***
>
> ***[Weâ€™ve previously explored how the crypto revolution represents a reversion to the earliest principles underpinning human commerce.](https://mirror.xyz/byzantineghost.eth/ompQ7hLHnenMTHcj9tHx18Y_UcUBVKDEmxh0HlOFrh4)***
>
> **Itâ€™s therefore only natural that one its biggest unlocks sees us return to the roots of our very nature**

title: The future of The Skribbles â€” Our plans for the upcoming months.
body:
The Skribbles has been an amazing adventure so far, full of learning experiences â€” which have allowed us to develop many new ideas. And we do not want to stop here.

Although we promised not to have a roadmap, we realize that there is something bigger to accomplish with the community we have managed to gather.

This is why we have decided to continue and do everything to make our project a success in the long-term. We wanted to share with you the outline of our plan to achieve our ambitious goals.

Note â€” The below roadmap will be given additions and more details throughout the coming months. It is also possible that some of the details change over time as events unfold.

**Step 1 - The Rebranding of The Skribbles**

Weâ€™re launching a second collection as you may already know. But why?

Firstly, since the initial collection mint was free, we found that many bots had the opportunity to mint multiple Skribbles. This leaves us with a large portion of holders who are actually just bots who mass minted. Therefore, most of our efforts to raise the floor price would be in vain, because at the slightest opportunity for profit, these bots would put the Skribbles they have minted up for sale. This would make it long and exhausting to get the floor price of our collection to increase.

Secondly, the collection weâ€™re currently working on has a completely different artistic direction. Therefore, we have to adapt our identity with this new collection for consistency and to avoid confusing newcomers. That's why we are going to reorganize our networks, our website, and our branding in general. The Skribbles will remain the backbone of our ecosystem until the mint of our new collection.

Finally, we have real ambitions for this new project. We want it to bring tangible utility to its holders. This is why it is essential to raise funds. This would allow us to hire more staff and alphas callers, create large-scale partnerships with big projects and simply continue to pursue the creation of great opportunities for our holders.

Don't worry â€” the collection will remain completely free to all Skribbles holders who meet the eligibility requirements.

**Step 2 - The Free Mint (For Skribbles Holders Only)**

Once we have redesigned our entire branding, and recruited all the people we need to get our second collection off the ground, we will start to communicate with the world, launch partnerships with other projects and distribute whitelists to the most active and engaged members.

Starting in mid-August, we will do our maximum to develop the community as well as to finish the collection we are working on.

The free mint will take place around mid-September.

We will reserve 1444 NFTs for our existing community, namely the Skribbles holders and those who have been hand selected to be part of the adventure due to their implication in the project.

By the way, we will reveal the name of the collection and the first sneak peeks soon.

**Step 3 - The Public Sale**

There will be a public sale for the rest of the supply. We plan to supply a maximum of 4444 NFTs in total for this new collection. So to sum up, 1444 for the Skribbles holders and 3000 for the public sale. We think it is healthier to have a smaller supply. The price has yet to be defined.

The public sale will take place two weeks after the free mint, by the end of September.

The time between the free mint and the public sale will be crucial. This will be the time to act as a close-knit community and all together keep our floor high as well as raise the hype around our project.

This time, we'll do everything we can to prevent bots from being part of the public sale. We will use Premint or a similar service to make a raffle with a minimum requirements to limit the possibility of bots entering our collection.

**Step 4 - The Beginning**

We want to make this new collection a real brand, we want to organize events, become a private and exclusive circle with the best alpha callers in the business, continue to partner with the biggest NFTs projects as well as brands, but most of all, we want to send you incredible new collections totally free - for all holders.

Because after all, we are creative, artists and that's why we got into NFTs. To make beautiful stuff and to have fun. One thing is for sure, we want to continuously improve the quality of the art of the collections we will create in the future.

We will continue to update this roadmap over time so you can continue to see what we are working on and what our plans are.

Thank you for taking the time to read this article.

You can't imagine how much we appreciate your presence and support.

â€” The Skribble Team

title: The future of The Skribbles â€” Our plans for the upcoming months.
body:
The Skribbles has been an amazing adventure so far, full of learning experiences â€” which have allowed us to develop many new ideas. And we do not want to stop here.

Although we promised not to have a roadmap, we realize that there is something bigger to accomplish with the community we have managed to gather.

This is why we have decided to continue and do everything to make our project a success in the long-term. We wanted to share with you the outline of our plan to achieve our ambitious goals.

Note â€” The below roadmap will be given additions and more details throughout the coming months. It is also possible that some of the details change over time as events unfold.

**Step 1 - The Rebranding of The Skribbles**

Weâ€™re launching a second collection as you may already know. But why?

Firstly, since the initial collection mint was free, we found that many bots had the opportunity to mint multiple Skribbles. This leaves us with a large portion of holders who are actually just bots who mass minted. Therefore, most of our efforts to raise the floor price would be in vain, because at the slightest opportunity for profit, these bots would put the Skribbles they have minted up for sale. This would make it long and exhausting to get the floor price of our collection to increase.

Secondly, the collection weâ€™re currently working on has a completely different artistic direction. Therefore, we have to adapt our identity with this new collection for consistency and to avoid confusing newcomers. That's why we are going to reorganize our networks, our website, and our branding in general. The Skribbles will remain the backbone of our ecosystem until the mint of our new collection.

Finally, we have real ambitions for this new project. We want it to bring tangible utility to its holders. This is why it is essential to raise funds. This would allow us to hire more staff and alphas callers, create large-scale partnerships with big projects and simply continue to pursue the creation of great opportunities for our holders.

Don't worry â€” the collection will remain completely free to all Skribbles holders who meet the eligibility requirements.

**Step 2 - The Free Mint (For Skribbles Holders Only)**

Once we have redesigned our entire branding, and recruited all the people we need to get our second collection off the ground, we will start to communicate with the world, launch partnerships with other projects and distribute whitelists to the most active and engaged members.

Starting in mid-August, we will do our maximum to develop the community as well as to finish the collection we are working on.

The free mint will take place around mid-September.

We will reserve 1444 NFTs for our existing community, namely the Skribbles holders and those who have been hand selected to be part of the adventure due to their implication in the project.

By the way, we will reveal the name of the collection and the first sneak peeks soon.

**Step 3 - The Public Sale**

There will be a public sale for the rest of the supply. We plan to supply a maximum of 4444 NFTs in total for this new collection. So to sum up, 1444 for the Skribbles holders and 3000 for the public sale. We think it is healthier to have a smaller supply. The price has yet to be defined.

The public sale will take place two weeks after the free mint, by the end of September.

The time between the free mint and the public sale will be crucial. This will be the time to act as a close-knit community and all together keep our floor high as well as raise the hype around our project.

This time, we'll do everything we can to prevent bots from being part of the public sale. We will use Premint or a similar service to make a raffle with a minimum requirements to limit the possibility of bots entering our collection.

**Step 4 - The beginning of an amazing adventure**

We want to make this new collection a real brand, we want to organize events, become a private and exclusive circle with the best alpha callers in the business, continue to partner with the biggest NFTs projects as well as brands, but most of all, we want to send you incredible new collections totally free - for all holders.

Because after all, we are creative, artists and that's why we got into NFTs. To make beautiful stuff and to have fun. One thing is for sure, we want to continuously improve the quality of the art of the collections we will create in the future.

We will continue to update this roadmap over time so you can continue to see what we are working on and what our plans are.

Thank you for taking the time to read this article.

You can't imagine how much we appreciate your presence and support.

â€” The Skribble Team

title: From Chicagoâ€™s South Side to Tech & Web3: The Journey of a First-Gen Low-Income Mexican-American
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/d4U-AghG5-knKE5RxeUbC.png?height=551&width=527)

I decided to share my story because I donâ€™t think there are enough stories of youth, who in their attempt to grow up quickly, make costly mistakes, yet still end up with jobs in Investment Banking, Tech, or Venture Capital.

Donâ€™t get me wrong, Iâ€™m luckier than a rabbit foot wrapped in a four-leaf clover inside a rainbow. But Iâ€™ve also lost family and friends to gang violence, and I donâ€™t take it for granted that I get to wake up every day to do the things Iâ€™m able to do.

## From Californiaâ€™s Strawberry Fields to Chicagoâ€™s South Side

My story starts with my Dad coming to the US in search of opportunities outside of his small ranch town in Guanajuato, MX. As an older sibling, he was pulled out of middle school to look after his younger siblings and the family livestock.

He had greater ambitions for himself and his family, so in his early 20â€™s, he crossed the border to work in the strawberry fields of California. He worked tirelessly to do a job many Americans wouldnâ€™t dream of doing, and for it he fought deportation every day.

Heâ€™s never been the giving up type (something Iâ€™ve inherited from him), and eventually he made his way to the steel factories on Chicagoâ€™s South Side. He saved up enough money to bring my mom to the US, and there on the South Side is where I was born and raised.

Like many kids in Chicago, I grew up with gangs. Iâ€™ve only begun to understand how thatâ€™s shaped my life. Around the neighborhood, we had the Vice Lords, the Latin Kings, the Gangster Disciples (GDâ€™s), and the Latin Dragons. Those names might not mean much to you, but in 2021, there were more than 3,500 shootings and 800 homicides in Chicago, concentrated in neighborhoods like mine, driven by names like those.

Growing up in these environments, youâ€™re just looking to survive. You do things like avoid certain streets, hide valuables when traveling, always watch your back, and limit time outside after dark. If youâ€™re wondering about crime enforcement, Iâ€™ve had a gun pointed at me twice in my life for no reason, once by a gangbanger, and once by a cop.

Itâ€™s hard to focus on schoolwork when this is your normal, but itâ€™s school that helped me change my circumstances. Iâ€™ve always had a growth mindset and was able to test into a magnet public high school by the name of Whitney M Young. It required that I take the train four hours every day, but it was my ticket out of the neighborhood.

## High School

At Whitney Young, I felt safe, which led me to deprioritize school work. I began capitalizing on my newfound freedom by selling mixtapes, designer clothes, iPods, bootleg this, and bootleg that. I started cutting classes, then failed a couple classes, then went to summer school, twice.

Eventually my recklessness caught up with me and I was almost expelled. Luckily, the school agreed to a parent-faculty conference before making it final and that meeting changed the course of my life.

As my parents sat there hearing how the school wanted to kick me out, I glanced over at my Dad and saw tears in his eyes. That image is still burned into my brain. My Dad sacrificed everything for his family, including his own education, and I was throwing it all away in the name of being my own man.

I promised to never again be that selfish, short-sighted, and ungrateful.

It was too late for me to get into a good college, so I decided to attend a for-profit college that eventually shut down. With that diploma came an eclectic, but intentional career focused on up-leveling.

## Early Career

I started my career as an Assistant Store Manager at Walmart. I spent three months there but quickly realized retail management wasn't for me.

I had been fascinated with Wall Street since high school when I participated in an after school program called Youth About Business. They hosted a Mergers & Acquisitions competition where the finalists traveled to NYC to visit banks and ring the closing bell on the New York Stock Exchange. I was a finalist and that visit opened my eyes to an entirely new world.

I didnâ€™t have the credentials to work in finance, but I was willing to play the long game and found a job at a Charles Schwab call center. It would pay $20,000 less than I was making at Walmart, and that was a lot of money to me. But I decided to take the pay cut since they sponsored employees for their Series 7 and 63 licenses, and that would be the start my career in finance.

Despite passing my licensing exams, it was hard to convince firms to take a chance on me without a fancy degree or network.

I made another bet and took a job with a temp agency in Chicago working in the back-office of Credit Suisse. It was a ten-week assignment and they needed someone with licenses to monitor trades and money movements. It wasnâ€™t glorious work, but I was grateful to be doing it. Once the temp assignment was up, they decided to bring me on full-time and I was officially working in finance.

My job was in the Private Wealth division helping the MBA interns with admin work so that they could find their first clients. I would check Bloomberg for people who recently sold their business so that the MBA interns could call them to ask if they needed help managing their new riches.

Soon after I caught a big break thanks to my soon-to-be mentor Jeff. Jeff was a Relationship Manager (RM) with an established book of business, and his small team of other RMs managed over $1 billion in client assets. I knew Jeff from casual interactions around the office, but seemingly out of nowhere, he asked me to be on his team so that I could work directly for him and his clients.

After a while it became clear that Jeff was an ally, and Iâ€™m grateful for him and allies like him that help others up the ladder knowing that their small act of generosity can have an outsized impact. Working for Jeff gave me the confidence to know that I belonged in finance. Not just in a call center or back-office; but as a trader, portfolio advisor, and capital allocator. To this day, I go to Jeff for advice on major life decisions and try my best to elevate others the same way he elevated me.

## Peace Corps

After a few years working for Jeff and being around MBAs, business school creeped onto my radar. However, up until that point, I had only lived in the Midwest and needed to see more of the world. So I applied to the Peace Corps, and was assigned to Peru as a Community Economic Development volunteer, a life experience I could not pass up.

For two years I served as a volunteer in the mountains of Peru with no running water and limited internet. I washed my clothes by hand. I took bucket baths that were warmed by the sun. And I traveled down a treacherous mountain road whenever I needed to submit business school applications.

During my service I taught youth entrepreneurship in the local high schools, hosted personal finance workshops for senior citizens, and launched a baseball academy for local boys & girls. It was a life-changing experience that taught me so much about the world and my place in it.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3UPLtS4Mt5qk1HF_2V89m.JPG?height=3456&width=4608)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/BDxDuMPd3WCSaaqL56Vxf.png?height=1286&width=1816)

My biggest takeaway was that despite my adversities, as an American, I was incredibly privileged by comparison.

My other takeaway was that despite being early in my career, I had knowledge and experiences that could positively impact the lives of many. I realized that even if you only learned a weekâ€™s worth of something, you can still teach it to someone who is just beginning.

## Business School / Investment Banking

After the Peace Corps, I began my MBA journey at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth.

I received a full-tuition scholarship thanks to Tuck donors and The Consortium. Without it, the $205,000 price tag would have been too much coming from the Peace Corps.

I owe so much to organizations like The Consortium, Management Leadership for Tomorrow (MLT), Toigo, and to generous donors who want to see more underrepresented minorities succeed in business school and beyond.

After business school, I went into investment banking and worked in New York as an Associate in the Global Industrials Group at Credit Suisse. I did that for a year, gained valuable modeling and valuation skills, developed an incredible network of highly motivated and brilliant individuals, but ultimately left because of the awful lifestyle.

100 hour+ weeks consumed by stress and sleepless nights for work that gets trashed with little to no notice. I went into banking the healthiest Iâ€™ve ever been thanks to the flexible MBA student lifestyle, but emerged from banking one year later in the worst shape of my life.

I left banking and began a self-discovery journey to find work that gave me balance and energy.

## Tech / Drift

After some reflection, I found myself gravitating towards entrepreneurship and tech. I was familiar with entrepreneurship, but not tech entrepreneurship. In the same vein, I was familiar with finance, but not Venture Capital.

I remember having a hard time understanding what a seed round was. Or why capital raises were called Series A, B, C, etc. Or how a VC could have 9 out of 10 investments fail, yet be successful.

I knew I wanted to be in the Tech ecosystem, but wasnâ€™t sure if as an operator or investor. Ultimately, I thought startup experience would make me a better investor and founder, so I opted for the operator route.

I wanted to work for a Black or Latinx founder since â€œyou canâ€™t be what you canâ€™t seeâ€, and was ecstatic to join Drift, a Latinx-founded B2B SaaS startup that recently became a unicorn.

I got the job thanks to Twitter and a Spanish jingle I wrote for them.

[https://twitter.com/OrlandoGomezzz/status/1337446027494891523?s=20&t=j2GXcWdIJeFEg9ZfIcX8WA](https://twitter.com/OrlandoGomezzz/status/1337446027494891523?s=20&t=j2GXcWdIJeFEg9ZfIcX8WA)

That jingle was my way of standing out as a candidate and highlighting my creativity. It was either going to peak their interest or get them to block me. Luckily, it was the former.

At Drift, Iâ€™m currently building out the Startups program so that early stage companies have the tools to accelerate revenue and have real conversations with their customers.

## Harlem Capital / Web3 Familia

Outside of Drift, Iâ€™ve been able to participate in amazing opportunities such as a VC internship with Harlem Capital. Thanks to them, I learned a ton about tech investing and was able to lean into my skills as a content creator (I also wrote them a jingle lol).

During my internship, I saw that Web3 was going to be bigger than I ever imagined. Seeing the sheer number of Web3 deals in the pipeline, and the amount of capital flowing into the capable hands of builders convinced me to go all-in on Web3.

Prior to that, I was a long-time skeptic of crypto. The banks I worked for assured me that crypto was not worth my time, and that it was primarily used to buy pizza and commit crimes.

However, what I was seeing with my own eyes at Harlem Capital painted an entirely different picture. This new picture was filled with opportunity and ownership, and I wanted in.

I had recently convinced my parents to invest in the stock market after ten years of struggling to get them comfortable with the idea, and I didnâ€™t want it to be another ten years before they, and other Latinos like them, got comfortable with crypto.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/zr4lnUpz9qk5mXxHBJ0nN.PNG?height=500&width=500)

So in November 2021, I launched Web3 Familia with the mission of onboarding 1 Million Latinos to Web3. It got instant traction and has become a community for Latinos to feel seen, heard, and empowered as Web3 learners and builders. We have since become an Education DAO on the NEAR Protocol and have raised seed capital thanks to NEARâ€™s DAOcubator program.

We are just getting started and Iâ€™m incredibly bullish on Latinos in Web3. This isnâ€™t just finance or tech. This is the intersection of finance, tech, and culture; and Latinos have culture for days.

## Final Thoughts

Looking back, my journey has not been a common one, but one common fact has permeated it. The fact that talent is equally distributed, but opportunity is not.

So if youâ€™re reading this as someone interested in Web3, Tech, VC, I-Banking, Business School, the Peace Corps, or any other field, just know that you belong in that space just as much as anyone else. You have the skills and talent necessary to achieve anything you set out to achieve. It might not appear that way at first, but donâ€™t give up. Sometimes you have to be the change.

[https://twitter.com/OrlandoGomezzz/status/1425502068027142148?s=20&t=j2GXcWdIJeFEg9ZfIcX8WA](https://twitter.com/OrlandoGomezzz/status/1425502068027142148?s=20&t=j2GXcWdIJeFEg9ZfIcX8WA)

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*Wng-JYfVu9c_mMsl.png)

Welcome to the Flipside Governance Team recap! Hereâ€™s a weekly summary of heady governance activity, our hard-hitting research & data analysis, and key news stories across the broader governance space.

### Team Highlights ğŸš¨

* \*\*Welcome Issy: \*\*Our team is growing! Isabel, our new Co-Op, joined this week and will be focusing on Research for her six month stint.
* \*\*Fig in Paris: \*\*Fig will be in Paris for the Ethereum Community Conference 5 (EthCC) from July 19th to July 21st. If youâ€™re around, please reach out (@francisgowen) to meet up!
* **Raph the Organizooor:** Raphael organized the MakerDAO Decentralized Voter Committee call which brought on Robert from the Collateral Services Engineering CU to speak on opportunities and coordination for collateral services.

### Our Research and Content âœï¸

* **[Oh, Snap! Setting up Snapshot Voting for Metagovernance](https://medium.com/flipside-governance/oh-snap-setting-up-snapshot-voting-for-metagovernance-be96737f5f16)**: Raphael walks through our efforts to become more transparent and sophisticated through introducing a system to our governance efforts (a way to govern our governance, aka metagovernance). Learn from our experience launching a token, setting up Snapshot, and implementing voting strategies in this piece.
* **[The Problem With Anons: Accountability in Web3](https://medium.com/flipside-governance/the-problem-with-anons-accountability-in-web3-30eb50860eb5)**: Figâ€™s first Op-Ed piece outlines the problems (and some positives) to anon culture in Web3. Read his (hot) take about the negative impacts on adoption and accountability due to this trend. No offense anons!

### Across the Industry: Governance News of the Week ğŸ“°

* **[StarkWare Confirms Launch of StarkNet Token](https://medium.com/starkware/part-1-starknet-sovereignty-a-decentralization-proposal-bca3e98a01ef)**: The token (10B tokens minted initially) is a step towards decentralizing the protocol and will allow supporters and contributors to play a role in governance. Additionally, the token will be required for payment of transaction fees on StarkNet and participation in StarkNetâ€™s consensus mechanism.
* **[Gnosis Safe Raises $100M and Rebrands to Safe](https://twitter.com/gnosisSafe/status/1546841782238859267?s=20&t=ZMeCQEFTVWWZUsYfy0hdjg)**: The popular DAO tooling and infrastructure provider enables secure management of digital assets, data and identity across DAOs, retail and institutional investors. The strategic funding round, led by 1kx, will enable Safe to continue growing an ecosystem of applications and tools on top of its protocol.
* **[Marinade DAO Executes Token Exchange Program](https://medium.com/marinade-finance/marinade-dao-executes-token-exchange-program-to-align-with-leading-solana-builders-2f61c6267c94)**: The Token Exchange Program will allow Marinade to exchange a total of 9.835M MNDE for 483k USDC and 500k SLND (an additional 1.2M MNDE will be distributed to SOL stakers). The exchange is the next step in decentralizing the DAO by giving key builders â€” Raydium, Solend, Port Finance and others â€” a vested interest in the future of the protocol.

### Flipside Governance | Analysis of the Week ğŸ“Š

The team published a **[MakerDAO Dashboard](https://app.flipsidecrypto.com/dashboard/mkr-holder-stats-jyDGFr)** to track changes in the demographics of MKR Holders over the last year (Jul 2021â€“2022). The below table shows that the number of MKR holders has increased by 8.63K.

![Data from Flipside Crypto](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*_PcAA345XYbe743LboUQDA.png)

The bar chart on the right shows that the percentage of MKR tokens held by CEXs, DEXs, and DeFi has dropped by \~5% while the percentage held by user addresses has increased by \~5%.

![Data from Flipside Crypto](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*-X-hICk0PSzSsd38RRDu-w.png)

The below pie charts show that the voting power among top ten holders has become more distributed. Note â€” the largest bucket is the Maker Governance Contract.

![Data from Flipside Crypto](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*tLkd3mdboIuaDajteC4Ehw.png)

### Flipside Governance Activity ğŸ“œ

The Flipside team voted in quite a few proposals this week, highlighted by another RWA vault onboarding proposal for MakerDAO. Hereâ€™s a recap of the proposals we voted on and the rationale for our votes:

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*Q8AzOPks-2IIegC-iwQihg.jpeg)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/CQoM1o7JgKU5yGCck6Ofh.png?height=2324&width=1640)

If you are interested in joining the Flipside Governance team, please email us at governance@flipsidecrypto.com or ping @avimeyers on Twitter.

VÃ¡rias organizaÃ§Ãµes desenvolveram mÃºltiplas aplicaÃ§Ãµes essenciais para o futuro das FinanÃ§as Descentralizadas. Um deles destaca-se pela capacidade de entrega e inovaÃ§Ã£o no desenvolvimento de ferramentas para a comunidade: **a Gnosis DAO**.

## Desenvolvedores Geniais Criam Ferramentas Fundamentais

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/SXJHYlidJqA2dzqoRERZz.png?height=700&width=1400)

A Gnosis DAO Ã© uma das organizaÃ§Ãµes mais capitalizadas do cripto-setor: [em seu tesouro repousam U$1.2B](https://openorgs.info/). A riqueza financeira da DAO nÃ£o Ã© por acaso. Fundada em 2015 como parte de *software* desenvolvido pela Consensys, tornou-se uma empresa independente em 2017 e desenvolveu mÃºltiplas soluÃ§Ãµes para a indÃºstria cripto.

Vamos mostrar a vocÃª os principais produtos pela Gnosis e porquÃª sÃ£o importantes para o cripto-mercado.

## Tokens Condicionais

Os tokens condicionais funcionam como mercados preditivos.

UsuÃ¡rios competem entre si em apostas de acontecimentos futuros, como eleiÃ§Ãµes presidenciais, quedas de regimes e jogos esportivos. A aplicaÃ§Ã£o pode parecer simples, mas a Gnosis introduziu a monetizaÃ§Ã£o tokenizada neste produto, possibilitando investimentos em ativos inimaginÃ¡veis - e tudo isso a necessidade de KYC ou moedas fiduciÃ¡rias -.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/72g_oaa4e6vGZ4SXq6nDs.png?height=1998&width=1400)

A Polymarket foi uma das primeiras plataformas a utilizou esta tecnologia como infraestrutura para construir sua prÃ³pria soluÃ§Ã£o de mercados preditivos, moldando-o ao seu produto e atraindo a atenÃ§Ã£o de usuÃ¡rios curiosos com a nova aplicaÃ§Ã£o.

## O inÃ­cio das *exchanges descentralizadas* e a proteÃ§Ã£o a MEV

Gradualmente, os desenvolvedores da Gnosis comeÃ§aram a encontrar outras mazelas na indÃºstria, destacando a ausÃªncia de liquidez em *exchanges* descentralizadas.

DeFi estava apenas despertando e a Gnosis sabia da importÃ¢ncia em construir infraestruturas para suportar o crescimento dos protocolos.

A 1Âª versÃ£o da DEX da organizaÃ§Ã£o, lanÃ§ada em 2020, introduziu o conceito de *ring trades,* negociaÃ§Ãµes compactadas em pequenos pacotes e enviadas coletivamente. Essa inovaÃ§Ã£o permitiu aos usuÃ¡rios economizarem em taxas de transaÃ§Ãµes e aumentarem a eficiÃªncia de seu capital, maximizando a liquidez para *trades.*

![Exemplo de ring trade implementado na V1 da Gnosis e futura CoW Swap](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RUgcZzr8L3RdS2hW9nc-o.png?height=818&width=1063)

Com o VerÃ£o DeFi despontando, aplicaÃ§Ãµes como estas foram essenciais para a comunidade. Muitos de seus conceitos foram importados da CoW Swap, uma DEX desenvolvida por seus programadores em 2018.  O protocolo trouxe funcionalidades especÃ­ficas, como a proteÃ§Ã£o a MEV - Miner Extractable Value -.

Escrevemos um texto explicando cada conceito de seu funcionamento e [vocÃª pode ler ele aqui.](https://mirror.xyz/foxbrasil.eth/OCJPvUWxnrDg9pG1rQEQ_dC3YxLs69hNtQwLhtYIvs8)

A evoluÃ§Ã£o do ecossistema e a rÃ¡pida adoÃ§Ã£o de seus produtos, fez a Gnosis inaugurar a V2 de seu protocolo e descentralizar a CoW Swap, tornando-a uma organizaÃ§Ã£o independente da empresa. Os *early adopters* receberam um *airdrop* com o token COW para votarem em propostas na governanÃ§a e decidir seu futuro.

Enquanto isso, mecanismos semelhantes aos da CoW Swap - proteÃ§Ã£o a MEV, melhoria na eficiÃªncia dos *ring trades* e atÃ© uma parceria com a Balancer - foram incluÃ­dos na 2Âª versÃ£o do protocolo da Gnosis.

## Custodiando BilhÃµes com Gnosis Safe

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3pX2A9aAsLhAsd8jgvhuC.png?height=645&width=1220)

O produto de maior sucesso da Gnosis, sem dÃºvida alguma, Ã© o [Gnosis Safe.](https://gnosis-safe.io/#getting-started) O protocolo desenvolvido para atuar como cofres para tesouros de DAOs teve larga adoÃ§Ã£o pela comunidade. title: Pool Party: Liquidity Mining in OP Summer
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0uwXxoCQN8VOBCDf2d1t0.png?height=1012&width=1908)

Weâ€™re introducing a new liquidity mining initiative as part of OP Summer: **Pool Party!**

Cool off in any of our liquidity pools and earn enhanced yields as a maker.

> *Learn more about [providing liquidity](https://blog.perp.fi/how-to-provide-liquidity-on-perp-v2-9064ed085d7f?source=your_stories_page-------------------------------------) on Perp v2.*
>
> *New to LPâ€™ing? Check out our [Easy LP feature](https://support.perp.com/hc/en-us/articles/5257563598617) to make it a breeze!*

Didnâ€™t receive invites to any pool parties this summer? No worries, as we have kicked off our very own!

As a new initiative for liquidity providers (LPs), Pool Party offers incentives in both OP and PERP tokens for facilitating volume on our DEX.

In case you missed it, we detailed the plans for our allocation of Optimismâ€™s governance token OP last month in a tweet thread:

[https://twitter.com/perpprotocol/status/1532821939936436224](https://twitter.com/perpprotocol/status/1532821939936436224)

To improve market depth and incentivize liquidity provision, weâ€™re distributing 8 million OP tokens to LPs. Read our full proposal [here](https://gov.optimism.io/t/gf-phase-0-proposal-perpetual-protocol/201).

And as part of this distribution, weâ€™re getting the pool party started with a big cheers to every single LP that has ever supplied liquidity by rewarding them with a retroactive airdrop!

## Retroactive OP AirdropğŸª‚

If youâ€™ve ever provided liquidity to any of the markets on [Perp v2](https://app.perp.com/?utm_source=perp_mirror&utm_medium=blog_post), then youâ€™re in for a surprise!

*Check [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1BUIh1Ba-oGX2lqnjab0FnJcuE8pY7qafPrHg3IcvlM8/edit?usp=sharing) to see if youâ€™re eligible.*

title: INTO THE HEKONAI JOURNAL
body:
An NFT should offer more value than a few rare traits that guarantee its scarcity. At CryptoAnime, we believe that NFTs should derive their value from the story they tell. Our NFTs play an essential role in an ongoing narrative, providing creative *utility,* meaning and purpose designed to push the story forward while unlocking new sources of income for the collaborating artists.Â  Our motto is best described as *"the story is the business model."*

... and the storyline behind the NFTs is just as unorthodox as the business approach. **Hekonai** is a "meta-narrative.â€ Its outer layer is designed to include everything you need in quality storytelling: distinctive characters, interesting events, relatable themes, a gamut of emotions, exotic settings, dramatic tension, plenty of excitement.

But that's not all it offers: on a second, deeper level, the unfolding plotline reflects the development of CryptoAnime itself in allegorical form. The idea is to offer entertainment that also weaves in commentary about NFTs, cryptofinance, Web3 and all the other brave new frontiers our company will explore.

Hekonai enters this storyline as a forgotten comic figure from the first anime. He becomes self-aware and takes control of his destiny as he travels into the metaverse to achieve his long-held dream of becoming a legendary samurai. His process of transformation drives a narrative that establishes meaning, purpose and utility for the NFTs that will explore the complexities of his new life as someone who can travel through several universes: animated, technological, even human life.

The story and digital assets will be complementary and interconnected in this meta-narrative format, each giving rise to the other as they interact with each other across multiple storylines and universes... including some generated by NFT holders. Sort of like the yin-yang symbol, with each side supporting and feeding into the other until they become indivisible.

![Relationship between Story and Digital Assets](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/61JVPuoIQvANVPDffthUz.png?height=838&width=685)

We've got lots of surprises coming your way on both story and tech fronts. But first, we need to introduce you to Hekonai. He's written a journal for you that will draw you into his brave new world.


___________________________________________________________________________________________

**Hekonai's Journal - Season I** will present over 20 short story entries in the form of 200-word posts, often accompanied by original illustrations commissioned and created by anime/manga-inspired artists from every corner of our world, and links to other online media curated to enhance your aesthetic experience.

You'll be there at every step as he tells you the tale of his rebirth in his own words. Don't be surprised if his travels through various interconnected universes challenge your notion of reality.

title: How I got I got here
body:
Farming is a profession of hope. I am from a Mexican-American family and a first-generation immigrant. My real father left my mother when she was pregnant with me. So I never got to meet him. Instead, I was raised by my stepfather, Mario, who raised my like one of his own (my step brothers and sisters). 

![From supporting my family with McDonald's pay, to my first successful crypto startup ](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KysY3yY1sBL3nv-kXZWkC.jpeg?height=554&width=378)

When I was a freshman at Osborne High School in Marietta, Georgia, my stepfather got deported after being pulled over while on his way to work as a pallet builder and recycler. He was deported after the officer told him he was an illegal immigrant without valid proof of citizenship. So at the age of 14, I had to take on the role and responsibility of head of household. On top of completing a high school education, I now had to take on a full-time job (40 hours a week) to support my younger siblings (2 brother and 2 sisters) and my mother who couldnâ€™t work.

Fortunately, my motherâ€™s brother who is a pastor in Garland, Texas had heard about the incident, and helped relocate us into a small 2 bedroom apartment in the summer of 2008. 

## The Westwood Village era 

![Rare ](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0XQhFCUsj36pnH2qp1T-W.jpeg?height=1124&width=1126)

Life was amazing. Even though I had dropped out of college and wasnâ€™t an academic student anymore, I was, an â€œhonorable UCLA studentâ€ lmao, according to my former mentor. 

## Building the Wikipedia of web3 

![Everipedia's first "corporate office" circa 2018. I forgot who took this photo lol.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xo84o3PB3R_EN7GqtXEnh.jpeg?height=960&width=1280)

During my first 2 years at Everipedia, I helped scale the operation to millions of pageviews a month. I was like a sponge. Teaching myself design, programming, and learning about Zk-proofs from â€œincelsâ€ from Sam Kazemian, one of the most important people I would ever meet in my life. 

## The Art of the Spam

![Google Analytics of Everipedia at over 1 million page views (circa 2017)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/1KAWQfzyp0eliHISYB3t3.jpg?height=546&width=881)

 A technique I pioneered at Everipedia, was called â€œThe Art of the Spamâ€, coined by co-founder and CTO Travis Moore. 

### The Covid pandemic era 

![During Covid, the Everipedia office became my home 24/7. I would take showers across the street at the public restrooms. ](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/6fAEj6CSxgwCmssV88Gs9.jpeg?height=1112&width=1104)
